Yes if both systems software can run out of sync , then the system clocks can be different. Then the clocks become having different time settings on screen and other things could be not working.then getting different time stamps and ending up in security certificates. Or system block.

content:
If you would like to remove an email account from Thunderbird without deleting the data, navigate to Account Settings in Thunderbird, select the account, and click Delete/Remove Account (red button, top-right of screenshot). Then, choose to remove account information only, leaving the other box, "Remove message data" unchecked.

This method should leave your messages and other data intact. Good Luck
creator: Thundamike

content: Have you tried Firefox Relay Premium?

content:
jgram2025 said

Have you tried Firefox Relay Premium?

No, and I don't want to — because I don't trust any infrastructure I don't control myself. That's why I prefer having my own solution.

Why do you think Firefox offers this service? All emails go through their system, and they can see and read your messages. Even if the content is encrypted, they still see the metadata — enough to build a user profile, especially with KYC-based payments.

content:
Now this is an interesting situation. Your problem is this: For some reason you have an incorrect set up. Your 'Inbox' contains two 'Drafts' folder and two 'Sent' folders and also the 'Archives' folder and maybe more folders like 'Junk' and 'Trash' None of those folders should be in the 'Inbox', they should be top level folders under 'Local Folders' and not subfolders to an 'Inbox' and you should not have two 'Drafts' and not have two 'Sent' folders.

Your Local Folders 'Inbox' contents is being shown in image so your profile folder image 'Local Folders' > 'Archives.sbd' > '2025.sbd' cannot be seen in Folder Pane. Your Folder Pane is saying this 'Local Folders' > 'Inbox.sbd' > 'Archives.sbd' > '2025'

I'm looking at your Folder Pane Under 'Local Folders' which I think is called 'dossiers locaux', but I cannot see the name in the image. I'm looking a folder called 'Courrier entrant' in English that is the 'Inbox' and it has an Inbox icon.

Please be honest...Have you attempted to move folders either in the Folder Pane or in the profile folders Local Folders folder ?

I need to see if you have more folders in the 'Local Folders'

  • In Folder Pane
  • Click on the > chevron to collapse the 'Archives' folder
  • Make sure 'Local Folders' is visible at the top.
  • I need to see all the folders you have in 'Local Folders' so I understand the entire structure.
  • Post image of Folder Pane showing everything in 'Local Folders'

But before I advise you to move them, I need to see what else is stored and where. This could be a little tricky as we do not want to lose anything.

Please make sure you always include the directory showing profile name > mail > local folders > etc as I need to be sure we are viewing the correct location. In profile folders please post an image showing all contents of:

  • 'Mail' folder
  • 'Local Folders' folder
  • Local Folders > 'Inbox.sbd' folder

Do you have more than one profile in the 'Roaming' > 'Thunderbird' > 'Profiles' folder ?

In 'Account Settings'

  • Select 'Local Folders' in left pane
  • On the right, look for 'Local Directory:'
  • Copy all the contents of what it says and post it into this forum or post an image but make sure we can see all the info.

This will tell me exactly where the current 'Local Folders' is looking.
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
Please note: I'm making my observations based on the images you have posted.

If you have made significant alterations to the 'Local Folders' account then it would be a good idea to let us know. But it is badly wrong to have all your folders in the Inbox. Thunderbird does not set up the 'Local Folders' account to have that structure.

Per poter inquadrare il problema prova a fornire queste informazioni:

  1. Versione di Thunderbird
  2. Versione del sistema operativo
  3. Provider delle caselle email (Gmail, Libero, Hotmail, etc.)
  4. Tipologia di account (POP3, IMAP)
  5. Estensioni installate
  6. Messaggi di errore che vengono visualizzati durante l'utilizzo di Thunderbird

  8. Screenshot del problema (se utile a chiarire il contesto)

content:
Thunderbird non ha mai avuto una funzione per l'ordinamento delle cartelle. Quindi o lo facevo con un altro software o utilizzavi qualche estensione. Se ti riferisci a Manually sort folders -> https://addons.thunderbird.net/en-US/thunderbird/addon/manually-sort-folders/?src=search non è più compatibile con Thunderbird da un paio di anni

Ogni cartella di Thunderbird è rappresentata da un file sul disco. Li trovi tutti nel Profilo https://support.mozilla.org/it/kb/profili-thunderbird#w_come-trovare-il-proprio-profilo in una sottocartella chiamata mail (POP3) o Imapmail (IMAP)

content:
Per quanto ne so l'ordinamento delle cartelle in Thunderbird è sempre alfabetico. Nelle versioni recenti è possibile ordinare la cartelle trascinandole nella posizione voluta. Se non viene più rispettato occorrerebbe capire cosa è successo. Quando scrivi in qualche modo sono riuscito a recuperarle non è affatto chiaro cosa hai fatto.

Se si è danneggiato il profilo utente, si fa prima a ripartire da un profilo pulito.

Inoltre, prova a fornire queste informazioni:

  1. Versione di Thunderbird
  2. Versione del sistema operativo
  3. Provider delle caselle email (Gmail, Libero, Hotmail, etc.)
  4. Tipologia di account (POP3, IMAP)
  5. Estensioni installate
  6. Messaggi di errore che vengono visualizzati durante l'utilizzo di Thunderbird
  7. Software di sicurezza eventualmente presenti (Antivirus e simili)
  8. Screenshot del problema (se utile a chiarire il contesto)
creator: @next

content:
Grazie della risposta inanzitutto, provo a spiegare meglio ciò che è succeso.

1- 140.0.1 2- Windows 11 3- Aruba (personalizzato) 4- POP3 5- QuickFolder ma successivamente all'accaduto, prima non erano installate estensioni 6- Nessuno 7- Nessuno

Pochi giorni fa ho creato una cartella denominata "Aziende" nella quale ho spostato varie cartelle (circa una 20ina con peso complessivo di 1,5Gb) all'interno, subito dopo l'operazione essa, insieme alle varie sottocartelle, è sparita nel nulla e solo con il riavvio di Thunderbird l'operazione in corso si è completata e le cartelle sono tornate visibili.

Successivamente ho denominato la nuova cartella in "Aziende A - K" (volevo creare delle Macrocartelle per aumentare l'efficenza durante la ricerca) e, appena fatto ciò, si è ripresentata la stessa identica situazione descritta precedentemente.

Dopo vari riavvi di Thunderbird e del PC la situazione non si era ancora risolta ed ho quindi provato ad accedere direttamente al file sul disco (%appdata%) dove vengono salvate le informazioni riguardo il gestionale.

In esso ho trovato "Aziende A - K" ancora presente e contenente le varie sottocartelle; per curiosità ho usato la funziona ricerca inserendo il nome di una sottocartella che sapevo essere scomparsa e, cliccandoci sopra, si è aperta una cartella paralella con lo stesso identico percorso file ma contenente le informazioni risalenti a prima della creazione della cartella "Aziende" in quanto essa non era presente.

Ho tagliato ed incollato questi file nel percorso originale sostituendo quelli precedenti.

Riavviando Thunderbird le cartelle ora risultano correttamente esistenti se non per il loro ordinamento, il quale è sparso e casuale, provando ad inserirne di nuove esse vengono messe infondo all'elenco avendo lo spostamento manuale come unica soluzione per riposizionarle.

Spero di essere stato chiaro con la spiegazione dato la strana natura dell'avvenimento, ero convinto anch'io che Thunderbird avesse un'ordinamento predefinito e probabilmente nel processo di spostamento tra le cartelle qualche file si è corrotto causando questo problema.

Con la speranza di poter risolvere ringrazio in anticipo chi mi aiuterà attendendo gentile risposta.
creator: info6710

content:
Hai creato la cartella Aziende in quale posizione? Sotto le altre cartelle del server? Sotto Cartelle locali?

Il resto è ancora più confuso di prima... C'è un gestionale che legge e scrive nella cartella del profilo di Thunderbird? Questa cosa è generalmente sconsigliata, nel profilo di Thunderbird dovrebbe lavorare solo Thunderbird. Il rischio è quello che dicevi anche tu: danneggiare un file di configurazione e rendere inutilizzabile l'applicativo.

Il problema potrebbe essere nel file prefs.js ma è difficile dire su quale parametro intervenire

Prova ad attendere qualche altre utente oppure prova a chiedere anche su https://forum.mozillaitalia.org/
creator: @next

content:
La cartella Azienda è sotto cartelle locali e non c'è nessun gestionale collegato.

Perdonami la confusione ma è talmente strano quello che è successo che non saprei nemmeno io cosa può essere la causa.

Dici che potrebbe essere necessario ricreare un nuovo profilo per risolvere il problema?
creator: info6710

content:
Creare un nuovo profilo significa partire da zero in uno spazio pulito. Il nuovo profilo infatti viene creato in una cartella differente rispetto al vecchio. In ogni momento inoltre puoi passare dall'uno all'altro -> https://support.mozilla.org/it/kb/utilizzare-piu-profili

Se usi IMAP come protocollo il nuovo profilo verrà sincronizzato con il server recuperando tutto. Se usi POP3 dipende dalle impostazioni del server e del vecchio profilo, in generale comunque la situazione peggiore è quella in cui scaricherai solo i nuovi messaggi e dovrai recuperare i precedente dal vecchio profilo.
creator: @next

creator: gerald.ten

content:
it is also almost always the result of an antivirus making things take to long. Do you have one scanning incoming mail perhaps. Or encrypted internet connections. Or a VPN which can cause all sorts of random issues with email ports/ connections with providers.

This link has a fairly good and simple to follow discussion on that happens when you attempt to get mail using pop. https://www.atmail.com/blog/pop-101-manual-pop-sessions/ In there they say that "STAT returns the number of messages in an inbox and their collective size (in octets)." 

STAT +OK 2 13410 
In this case, 2 messages totalling 13,410 octets (or more commonly, bytes).

That this command is failing would indicate your authentication has failed or timed out. (that antivirus,VNP idea), without Thunderbird being aware this has occurred. To be sure you would need to log the evets and report the information in the log. To enable this you would use the Config Editor to modify the hidden preference mailnews.pop3.loglevel, to All.

After you attempt to get mail and fail, open the error console( Alt+Ctrl+J) to view the errors and from there you can copy then and paste into a reply on the forum or into a text file. But before trying to get details, I would simply disable the antivirus scanner to see if it is the problem as that is the easiest thing to do first.
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
You posted: "When trying to send an encrypted mail to somebody new, I get an error “End-to-end encryption requires resolving certificate issues with somebody@example.com”.

The message is not very helpful, and doesn’t propose any solution. So a web search gave me this article: Prerequisite for sending an encrypted email message. It states:

> If Thunderbird considers the email's signature and the sender's certificate valid, it will automatically be imported and available when you attempt to encrypt an email to that correspondent using the S/MIME technology.

When I open the sender’s mail, the signature is confirmed as valid by Thunderbird."

Didn't you say in the beginning that you had an error message?

Thunderbird is an email client that queries CRLs (the whole procedure seems to be undergoing changes). What more do you think tbird can do about someone elses ctfs?
creator: jeff-g

content:
Hi, thanks for your answer.

Yes, that’s exactly the point.

The nuance is that I get an error when trying to *send* (i.e. encrypt) the mail—not when reading it or verifying the certificate and the signature.

I’d expect tbird to import the certificate once I open the sender’s mail, which it doesn’t seem to do.

Maybe the changes broke it?

Is there any manual way to import that certificate?
creator: p6

content:

creator: christ1

content:
Hi and thanks for helping.

Yes, there’s an error in the console when trying to send the message encrypted:

`mailnews.send: NS_ERROR_ILLEGAL_VALUE: Component returned failure code: 0x80070057 (NS_ERROR_ILLEGAL_VALUE) [nsIMsgComposeSecure.beginCryptoEncapsulation]`

It’s hard to tell if it’s always happening, since I don’t receive S/MIME-signed mails from unknown senders every day. If you could send one to test, that’d be great! You can send to smime@ux-t.dev
creator: p6

content:
So, I verified in my list of certificates for people, and that new person didn’t figure in the list. Other people did, the last one from 6 June.

When the cert from the new contact wasn't imported into your Thunderbird's certificate store I'd suspect a problem with that cert. Due to the lack of a valid cert you do get the error message when attempting to send an encrypted message to that recipient.

Is there any manual way to import that certificate?

Ask the owner of the problematic cert to send it as an email attachment. You can then try to import it into Thunderbird. At the top right of the Thunderbird window, click the menu button ≡ > Settings - Privacy & Security - Certificates - Manage Certificates

In the Certificate Manager select the 'People' tab, and click Import

If you could send one to test, that’d be great!

I don't want to do that.
creator: christ1

content: It is supposed to help if you routinely and periodically flag the good and bad. If I may offer an unofficial suggestion, install the free Mailwasher program (it's free for one account).. run it prior to starting thunderbird and you will get a better picture of your spam - and this free tool can eliminate the spam if you run it first. And, if the messages are spam coming into Mailwasher, that will be helpful to know. I've used this tool for years
creator: davidsk

content:
Lets back up.

1. Thunderbird does not under any circumstance use the word SPAM, let alone insert it into email subjects or bodies. So the source is external to Thunderbird.

2. As Wayne suggest SpamAssassin is well known to do exactly that, insert the word spam in the subject of mail. This approach is not limited to that particular tool however. While is is a popular choice of some email providers, the likes of Outlook, Google, GMX or Yahoo do not use it. You have not, that I can see, mentioned who provides the email service so I have no idea if that is relevant.

3. Hosted domains which come with a mail offering, along with corporate email services almost all have some form of server side spam filtering. This topic at Google discusses determining the source of such a detection by looking in the message source (that is CTRL+U in Thunderbird). https://support.google.com/mail/thread/14798766/emails-being-sent-to-people-with-spam-headers?hl=en

4. Some antivirus products think they are the spam police and scan for spam and love sticking big and often incorrect labels on things. They think it encourages your trust and your commitment to keep paying for their questionable services if they are seen to be doing something. Do you and your wife share a common antivirus product?

5. Email headers (ctrl+U) that begin with an X- are non standard headers. They are also where we get most of the diagnostic information about email being modified by spam filters. So have a look at the headers for some of your spam messages. look specifically for things like; X-Forefront-Antispam-Report: and X-Microsoft-Antispam: they are the filters for office365. https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/defender-office-365/message-headers-eop-mdo

X-Spam-Level and X-Spam-Status. the SpamAssassin headers https://www.mailercheck.com/articles/how-to-read-and-understand-email-headers#bonus-spamassassin-email-headers

You might even find notes in the headers from your personal antivirus telling you it did the deed. X-headersis largely a free format thing, so what is in headers, while it can look very technical frequently offers a wealth of information to an open mind that is looking for anything that looks "wrong" or out of place.

bob422 said
What is "Collected Addresses"? I have never touched the settings here.

It is a default setting in Thunderbird, when you send an email to someone you do not have in your address book that address is added to the collected addresses address book.

By enabling the setting here they are by default now included in the whitelist for Junk filtering when they reply. Generally we expect a reply to emails, or at least I do.

The existence of an OSX address book in your image would indicate the dreaded apple operating system, so I would expect you to be having an antivirus and to be unfamiliar with just how troublesome they are because it is only in recent years apple products have had the market share to be targets for malware.

Note: The OSX address book is entirely read only in Thunderbird, so it also can be very frustrating if most of your contacts are in it.

creator: chattome

content:
Suggestion:

  1. click 'account settings'
  2. scroll down to 'Outgoing Servers (SMTP) and click there
  3. for each SMTP entry, change the DESCRIPTION field to contain the email address for the account. Check also that the User Name field for that account is correct.
  4. then, still within account settings, click the account name in left side for each account. On the right side that displays info for the account, look at bottom line where there is the link to 'Outgoing server SMTP'. What you see there should be what you entered in prior step for DESCRIPTION field. If not, then click the dropdown menu there and select the appropriate SMTP server.

Doing the above may correct your problem if sending with the wrong account.

content: Thunderbird would have difficulties if installed with a profile point to drive D when there is nothing on drive D. and that must have been the situation, at least briefly. I suggest you attempt to fully duplicate what you had on old PC. That is, install same version (if possible) of version on new PC and exit. Then, exit thunderbird on old pc. Now, using windows file explorer copy the appdata\roaming\thunderbird folder to the same location on new PC. Do NOT start thunderbird yet. Now, assuming a new drive D, copy the old Thunderbird folder on D to the new D so that it is in the same location from a disk perspective. Now, starting thunderbird it should not even realize it is on a new PC.

content: Here is what may be a simple fix: - exit thunderbird - in windows file explorer, click to c:\users\<yourid>\appdata\roaming\thunderbird - open the text file, profiles.ini - this is where thunderbird looks for the location of the profile. if the profile address is not there, thunderbird shuts down. key in the address, save and exit and restart thunderbird

content:
Ok, I am the mad one that says the machine transfer is fundamentally broken. I am assured it is fine and I am just not understanding the new ways of doing things. I am certainly done filing bug to reports this stuff as broken.

However some of the old and true approaches still work as far as they go. They require a little bit of copy and paste but I have had success with folk doing it the following way.

Open your old copy of Thunderbird and go to the troubleshooting information on the help menu. Open the profile folder using the button in the application basics part on the first screen

Close Thunderbird as it needs to be not running in the background for this next step. It does not cope well with the copying and replacing of it's profile while it is running. In the file manager that opens copy everything in the folder and any sub folders to a spare USB drive, clearly one larger that 4Gb will be required. Ctrl+A will select everything for a drag and drop copy.

Open your new shiny install of Thunderbird and go to the troubleshooting information on the help menu of that instance. Open the profile folder using the button in the application basics part on the first screen

Again close Thunderbird. Now copy everything you copied from the old profile into the new one.

Note: Unless you get error messages asking to replace stuff you have done it wrong, you are replacing one profile with another. You must opt to replace in those cases.

Start your new copy of Thunderbird everything should "just be there and work." although the antivirus and software firewall on the new machine might cause some issues.
creator: MattAuSupport
